sections.title: Piaget's Cognitive Development Theory
sections.summary:
## ğŸ§  Core Concepts

Children actively adapt to their world through building mental **schemas** (plans/patterns about how things work).

Intelligence develops through stages, not just accumulating facts.

## âš™ï¸ Key Processes

â€¢ **Schemas** - Mental frameworks to understand world
  - Example: 'classroom schema' includes desks, board, chairs
â€¢ **Assimilation** - Adding new experiences to existing schemas
  - Child calls airplane 'bird' because it flies
â€¢ **Accommodation** - Changing schemas when they don't fit
  - Realizing airplanes aren't birds - they're metal, carry passengers
â€¢ **Equilibrium** - Mental balance when schemas explain all experiences

## ğŸ“ˆ Development of Intelligence

Built through progressing through stages and creating/modifying schemas.

*Example:* Child's 'bird schema' evolves from 'things that fly' to understanding differences between birds and planes.

## ğŸ“ Educational Applications

â€¢ Discovery learning
â€¢ Focus on thinking processes not just right answers
â€¢ Acknowledge children think differently than adults
â€¢ Individual-paced learning

## âœ… Strengths & âŒ Weaknesses

**Strengths:** Practical applications, generated extensive research, explains how children build knowledge.

**Weaknesses:** Ignored cultural/social influences, subjective interpretations, some studies show children can do things earlier than Piaget thought.

sections.title: Dweck's Mindset Theory
sections.summary:
## ğŸ”’ Fixed vs Growth Mindset

### Fixed Mindset
â€¢ Believes abilities are **unchangeable**, innate
â€¢ When praised for being 'smart', children think ability is fixed
â€¢ Leads to: avoiding challenges, giving up easily, ignoring feedback
â€¢ Can cause depression and learned helplessness

### Growth Mindset
â€¢ Believes **practice and effort** improve abilities
â€¢ When praised for effort, children persist through challenges
â€¢ Embrace feedback, learn from failures, inspired by others' success

## ğŸ’¬ Impact of Praise

â€¢ **Person praise** ('You're so smart!') â†’ Fixed mindset
â€¢ **Process praise** ('You worked really hard!') â†’ Growth mindset
â€¢ Teachers' mindsets affect how they view student potential

## ğŸ“ˆ Research Evidence

â€¢ **Mueller & Dweck (1998)** - Ability praise led to fixed mindset and vulnerability to setbacks
â€¢ **Yeager & Dweck (2012)** - 1500+ students, low achievers with growth mindset training performed better

## ğŸ“ Educational Implications

â€¢ Focus on praising **effort and strategies**, not intelligence
â€¢ Teach that brain can grow and change
â€¢ Emphasize learning process over grades
â€¢ Help students see mistakes as learning opportunities

## âœ… Strengths & âŒ Weaknesses

**Strengths:** Practical applications, positive theory showing change is possible, research support.

**Weaknesses:** Many studies in artificial lab settings, may oversimplify complex learning factors.

sections.title: Willingham's Learning Theory
sections.summary:
## ğŸ“š Factual Knowledge First

Skills like problem-solving and reasoning require **prior factual knowledge**.

*Example:* Understanding 'she has more likes than me' needs knowledge of social media 'likes'.

Knowledge frees up working memory space for higher-order thinking.

## ğŸ§  Working Memory

â€¢ **Limited capacity** system with separate processing for:
  - Visual information
  - Auditory information
  - Decision-making component
â€¢ When facts are automatic, more mental space available for complex thinking

## ğŸ’ª Practice and Effort

Essential for mastery - must practice until skills become **automatic**.

*Quote:* 'Don't practice until you get it right, practice until you can't get it wrong.'

Applies to:
â€¢ Knowledge (rehearsal â†’ long-term memory)
â€¢ Motor skills (muscle memory through repetition)

## ğŸ“ˆ Development Strategies

### Cognitive Development
â€¢ Use problems within student ability but requiring effort
â€¢ Understand developmental stages but remember abilities vary day-to-day
â€¢ Consider factors beyond development (task understanding, motivation)

### Physical Development
â€¢ Motor skills improve through **conscious practice** of movement sequences
â€¢ Focus on suitable movements, practice in correct order

### Social Development
â€¢ Challenges Piaget - believes children can take others' perspectives by **18 months** (not 7 years)
â€¢ Strategies: demonstrate appropriate behavior, control impulsive behavior, encourage self-regulation

## âœ… Strengths & âŒ Weaknesses

**Strengths:** Practical applications, draws from multiple areas of cognitive science, experimental support.

**Weaknesses:** Doesn't emphasize individual differences enough, not one testable theory.

sections.title: Three Mountains Study (Piaget & Inhelder, 1956)
sections.summary:
## ğŸ”ï¸ Background

Tested Piaget's theory that **pre-operational children** (2-7) are egocentric - can only see world from their own viewpoint.

**Concrete operational children** (7+) can 'decentre' and see others' perspectives.

## ğŸ”¬ Method

â€¢ **100 children** aged 4-12
â€¢ Used 1mÂ² model with **3 mountains:**
  - Green (lowest, house on top, winding path) ğŸ 
  - Brown (middle, red cross, stream) â•
  - Grey (highest, snow-covered) â„ï¸
â€¢ 10 photographs from different viewpoints
â€¢ Wooden doll with no facial features

## ğŸ“‹ Procedure

Three tasks:
â€¢ Use cardboard shapes to show mountain view from different positions
â€¢ Choose photographs showing what they/doll could see
â€¢ Position doll to match given photograph viewpoint

## ğŸ“ˆ Results

### Pre-operational (4-6.5 years)
â€¢ Always chose **their own view**, even when asked for doll's perspective
â€¢ Couldn't position doll correctly
â€¢ Showed **egocentrism** throughout

### Concrete operational (7+ years)
â€¢ Gradually understood others have different views
â€¢ By 9-10, could accurately show doll's different perspective
â€¢ Could coordinate multiple viewpoints

## ğŸ¯ Conclusion

Supported Piaget's stages - younger children egocentric, older children can **decentre**.

Provided evidence for stage-based cognitive development.

## âœ… Strengths & âŒ Criticisms

**Strengths:** Detailed qualitative data, experimental controls, reliable findings across many children.

**Criticisms:** Other studies with more realistic tasks found children could decentre earlier:
â€¢ Borke (1975) - 3-year-olds **79% correct** with Sesame Street character
â€¢ Task may have been too abstract/unrealistic for younger children

sections.title: Parent Praise Study (Gunderson et al., 2013)
sections.summary:
## ğŸ  Background

Built on Dweck's mindset theory using **natural home settings** instead of artificial lab experiments.

Previous research showed praise type affects children's beliefs about ability and effort.

## ğŸ—£ï¸ Person vs Process Praise

### Person Praise
*'You're so smart!'*
â€¢ Praising the individual â†’ Entity theory (abilities are fixed)
â€¢ â†’ **Fixed mindset** â†’ Less likely to try hard on difficult tasks

### Process Praise
*'You worked really hard!'*
â€¢ Praising behavior/effort â†’ Incremental theory (abilities can change)
â€¢ â†’ **Growth mindset** â†’ More likely to persist and improve

## â™€ï¸â™‚ï¸ Gender Differences

Previous studies suggested:
â€¢ **Boys** receive more process praise â†’ incremental theory
â€¢ **Girls** receive more person praise â†’ entity theory
â€¢ May explain some gender differences in academic persistence

## ğŸ”¬ Method

â€¢ **Longitudinal study** following 53 children (29 boys, 24 girls)
â€¢ From 14-38 months old
â€¢ Participants: 64% white, 17% African-American, 11% Hispanic, 8% multiracial
â€¢ Parents didn't know praise was being studied
â€¢ Recorded **natural parent-child interactions** at home
â€¢ Five years later, measured children's motivational frameworks

## ğŸ¯ Aims

â€¢ Test if natural parental praise affects children's later reasoning
â€¢ Examine if parents give different praise types to boys vs girls
â€¢ See if early praise predicts later motivational beliefs

## ğŸŒ¿ Ecological Validity

**Major strength** - used natural home environment rather than artificial lab setting.

Provides more realistic understanding of how praise actually affects children.

## ğŸ“š Connection to Education

Supports teaching parents and teachers to focus praise on **effort and process** rather than innate ability or intelligence.
